hints_raw: Which differentiation rules will you be using here?
question: 1 (k)
sols_html:
We compute this derivative using the chain rule twice and the product rule

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt} &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot \frac{d}{dt}( t\cos(2t))\\ &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot (\frac{d}{dt}(t) \cdot \cos(2t) + t \frac{d}{dt}(\cos(2t)))\\ &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot ( 1 \cdot \cos(2t) + t (-\sin(2t) \cdot 2))\\ &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \left( \cos(2t) - 2t\sin(2t) \right)\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We compute this derivative using the chain rule twice and the product
rule

\begin{align*}
\frac{dy}{dt} &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot \frac{d}{dt}( t\cos(2t))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot (\frac{d}{dt}(t) \cdot \cos(2t) + t \frac{d}{dt}(\cos(2t)))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot ( 1 \cdot \cos(2t) + t (-\sin(2t) \cdot 2))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \left( \cos(2t) - 2t\sin(2t) \right)
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We compute this derivative using the chain rule twice and the product rule

:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{dy}{dt} &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot \frac{d}{dt}( t\cos(2t))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot (\frac{d}{dt}(t) \cdot \cos(2t) + t \frac{d}{dt}(\cos(2t)))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot ( 1 \cdot \cos(2t) + t (-\sin(2t) \cdot 2))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \left( \cos(2t) - 2t\sin(2t) \right)
\end{align}
</math>

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=e^{t\cos({2t})}\end{aligned}\]
